message: Hi Team, here's a quick summary of what I've gathered from the project description and the test cases that were provided to us:

Pre-Task:\n - Use the Apache POI library to import data from the Details, Data, and Attendance worksheets from the GradesDatabase6300.xlsx file\n - There are a whole bunch of other sheets in the Excel file that we will probably be using for the next Deliverables but don't seem to be required for this first Deliverable.

Task 1: Develop a class (Student) that holds the information about a student, such as name and GT ID.
 - stu = new Student()
 - stu.getName() [returns String]
 - stu.getGtid() [returns String]
 - stu.getAttendance() [returns int]

Task 2: Develop a class (GradesDB) that encapsulates most of the system functionality and provides an intuitive interface towards the information in the spreadsheet.
 - db = new GradesDB(Constants.GRADES_DB)
 - db.getNumStudents() [returns int]
 - db.getNumAssignments() [returns int]
 - db.getNumProjects() [returns int]
 - db.getStudents() [returns HashSet<Student>]
 - db.getStudentByName(String name) [returns Student]
 - db.getStudentById(String gtid) [returns Student]
Additionally there will probably need to be setters or a constructor function where you can pass in the needed parameters for creating the new Student instances.

Next up will be divvying the tasks (it seems like the constructor for GradesDB where the Excel data will be imported / assembled into a usable data structure will probably be the most time intensive part of this Deliverable)

This article contains a decent tutorial on how to use the Apache POI's XSSF classes for reading info from .xlsx files:\nhttp://viralpatel.net/blogs/java-read-write-excel-file-apache-poi/\n("Working with .xlsx files" section)

Hmm...now I'm having a few doubts now that I'm thinking about this a bit more (looking at the expectations for the next two deliverables).

Since the course is more about process than anything else, in some ways if we build ahead of the Story / Task Cards that'll be provided to us in Deliverable2, then it'll make building the JUnit Tests next week not as meaningful.

And if we build code ahead of time that won't be needed until Deliverable3 (before we have the JUnit tests) then it also makes that process less meaningful as well (since the Test Driven Development model has you creating the tests first and then the code to make them pass).

So now I'm feeling maybe working ahead might be frowned upon a bit because we'd be circumventing the "TDD" process.

On the one hand I'm all for moving ahead, but looking at the bigger picture of the process we're supposed to be learning about, perhaps it might not actually be a great idea.

What do you guys think?
Looking at thenew expectations now.
